subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] What language tags for Quikscript?
msgSnippet: ... Correct. ... It is more likely that we will wait till discussions about the encoding proceed, than to encode a script tag in advance of a decision. ...
messageBody:
On 4 May 2013, at 03:27, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:

> One question to be answered first is whether Quikscript should be coded as a variant of Shavian script, in the same sense that German Fraktur script is coded as a variant of Latin script.

Correct.

> ISO 15924 defines a script variant as a "particular form of one script which is so distinctive
> a rendering as to almost be considered a unique script in itself". I think Quikscript qualifies. If so, I think we should request the code Shaq (variants differ in the last letter only), if not, the code Quik.

It is more likely that we will wait till discussions about the encoding proceed, than to encode a script tag in advance of a decision.

> This issue is independent of Unicode unification or disunification and does not prejudice it either way. Fraktur letters are unified with ordinary Latin,

Because they're Latin.

> but the three script variants of Georgian are not unified in Unicode.

Because they're not actually script variants. A restaurant menu can be printed in Fraktur and people are expected to be able to read it. No Georgian even recognizes Khutsuri without special training.

Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com/
